summary.p: Received the two letters with the recommendations of Johannes Fabricius [Hans Schmid] and the Franciscan; Fabricius could barely answer the usual examination questions and was therefore provided with good advice. The Franciscan was sent on to Constance; there are too many local poor people with whom both the council and the administrators of the church properties are excessively burdened, and the price demanded by the craftsmen [for an apprenticeship] was too high for Bullinger with his large family. Regarding Myconius' accusation that he is silent: Bullinger responded to Myconius' last public letter [No. 1866] [No. 1877], but Myconius has not reacted since; Bullinger maintains that Myconius has interpreted the words "This is my body" differently than before, as he is said to have stated: "Wett, the devil taught them to interpret the Lord's words 'this is my body' as 'this means my body'"; if this is true, the Holy Scripture and the Church Fathers must be opposed to him, otherwise Myconius' response [No. 1866] suggests that he has lost his former simplicity and clarity; however, assures him of his friendship. Recommends the bearer Bernhard Lindauer, who wants to study and is about to travel to Hesse.

div.p: Grace and peace from the Lord.

I received two letters from you, dear Myconius. In the first, you recommended Johannes Fabricius [Hans Schmid] to us; when we examined him as per our custom, he responded so coldly, or rather not at all, that we were all forced to marvel and feel sorry for him.
Nevertheless, we gave the poor man some advice. If he follows it, we hope it will turn out well for him.

In the second, you recommended the Franciscan, whom we received kindly, but then sent him on his way to Constance with provisions. I did not want to plead his case with the magistrate or the deacons of the church, who I believe are the administrators of church properties. I know that there are more poor citizens and locals than can be helped according to their needs, and I do not willingly burden those who are already sufficiently burdened. The price that the craftsmen demanded from me was more than I could commit to, as I saw that it would have to be paid from my own resources. Indeed, my family is already quite large. Therefore, I gave him provisions and a recommendation. I also gave him advice and sent him to Constance.
I could do nothing else at present.

In your last letter, you write: "You write nothing, you respond to nothing, you do not greet, you act as if you never knew me," etc. What should I write, my dear Myconius, or what should I respond? I wrote in my own name and in the name of the brothers. But you were so disturbed and agitated by that letter as by nothing else. I responded to your last public letter, and what I thought pertained to me, I did not treat in passing, but I addressed. However, you have not responded to it until now. I did not present the public letters to the brothers for no other reason than what I indicated in my letter. Before God and with you, I freely and sincerely say that your opinion on the Eucharist, which you hint at, does not agree with the one you once followed, or I do not understand you. Once, the Catholic interpretation of Christ's words: "This is my body," that is, "This is the sign, figure, memory of my body," was pleasing. But now you say: "Wett, the devil taught them to interpret the Lord's words 'this is my body' as 'this means my body'." If you said so, I respond that Scripture and the holy fathers provide us with that interpretation, which I can demonstrate with clear and most effective testimonies. If you did not say so, what you wrote in your last and public letters is such that, unless I do not understand you, they do not have your former simplicity and clarity. This grieves my heart. Otherwise, my feelings towards you have not changed. I love you, respect you, and wish you all the best. You will find a friend and brother, you will praise faith and love, wherever you need my help.
The bearer of this letter, Bernhard Lindauer, a young scholar, wishes to see and hear the learned. He is traveling to Hesse. I commend him to you. Farewell.
To D. Oswald Myconius, most vigilant bishop of the Basel church, dearest brother.
